titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Brian Carpenter

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T21:14-0400

did.unittitle: Shawnee language recordings
did.abstract: The collection consists of linguistic elicitations of different aspects of Shawnee grammar and vocabulary, and conversation, anecdotes, discussion, and personal narratives relating to Shawnee customs and history. The linguistic material includes elicitation of passive, imperative, hortative verbs, and other verb forrms, vocabulary for times of the day and year, weather, gender and age, color terms, and miscellaneous adjectives and full sentences. The other material includes a narratives given in Shawnee on on traditional roles of men and women and the use of eagle feathers in doctoring, and English anecdotes and conversation relating to topics such as: different types of dances, the Shawnee Indian Agency, economic and agricultural conditions during the Depression, memories of farming and hunting during childhood, traditional medicine, the keeping of fire, how people and tribes were created and how they learned to make fire, the treatment of women in Shawnee society, little people, the passing down of knowledge through elders, doctoring, the use of tobacco and peyote, and personal stories. Recorded in Oklahoma in 1994.
did.physdesc: 26 sound tape reels (12 hr., 21 min.) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Amoena Norcross in 1995 (Acc. 1995-1233r). This material was recorded with the assistance of a Phillips Fund grant.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission required from collector for duplication of recordings. Please contact a curator for details.

did.unittitle: Audio recordings
Elicitation of Shawnee sentences with color terms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Elicitation of Shawnee grammatical constructions primarily focused on colors (red and black) in animate and inanimate, and singular and plural forms.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Sound tape reel) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.

did.unittitle: Conversation on Shawnee customs and beliefs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Conversation on miscellaneous Shawnee customs and beliefs with some vocabulary. Discusses prohibition on playing or eating after dark, customs surrounding a feast for a person who has died, little people who live in trees, little lost people, and how babies are named. In English only.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Sound tape reel) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.

did.unittitle: Conversation on Shawnee customs and beliefs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Conversation on little people, the consultant's mother's medicine, the naming of babies, a personal anecdote about sickness, and the passing down of knowledge through elders. In English only.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Sound tape reel) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.

did.unittitle: Conversation on how people were created, treatment of Shawnee women, and miscellaneous customs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begins with some elicitation, followed by story of how people and tribes were created and how they learned to make fire. Continues into discussion of the keeping of fire, the treatment of women in Shawnee society, and related customs. Predominantly in English.

did.unittitle: Story of Grandmother's grandson who mistreated animals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Story given in English, then in Shawnee, followed by a discussion of Shawnee beliefs regarding treatment of animals and animals' conferring of powers to humans. Also discusses the role of dogs in going to heaven.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Primarily includes elicitation of sentences using Shawnee verbs for wearing, with discussion of types of clothing and worn objects, common and traditional. Also includes discussion of different ways to ask questions. Discussion from 15:35 to 18:30 of Corn Lady.
